metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
defendants: E1 Entertainment Television, LLC and Anr.
respondents: E1 Entertainment Television, LLC and Anr.
key_issues: Maintainability of the rectification petition in view of the judgment of the Supreme Court in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors.
Applicability of Section 124 read with Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, regarding the requirement of framing a preliminary issue in a suit before filing a rectification application.
Whether the petitioner's awareness of the respondent's trademark registration since 2018 and failure to challenge it in a previous suit bars the present rectification petition.
Interpretation of the judgments of the Supreme Court and the Coordinate Bench of the Delhi High Court in Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr.
Scope of the rectification petition and whether it is limited to the trademark registration No. 1252812 in class 99.
Relevance of the petitioner's claim of proprietary rights over the trademark "NOW" and "NOW" formative marks, including "ENOW", in the context of the rectification petition.
Effect of the petitioner's failure to have a preliminary issue framed on the alleged invalidity of the respondent's trademark in the previous suit.
Applicability of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, in determining the validity and maintainability of the rectification petition.
Whether the subject matter of the rectification petition is the same as the subject matter of the previous suit, CS(COMM) 253/2019.
Procedure for rectification of trademark registration under the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and the role of the court in determining the maintainability of such petitions.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**
The case involves a trademark rectification petition filed by Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited (the Petitioner) against E1 Entertainment Television, LLC (the Respondent) in the High Court of Delhi. The Petitioner seeks to rectify the trademark register regarding the Respondent's trademark registration No. 1252812, which is registered in Class 99 (Classes 38 and 41) since December 2, 2003.

**Legal Issues:**
The main issue in this case is whether the Petitioner's rectification petition is maintainable, given that the Petitioner was aware of the Respondent's trademark registration since June 6, 2018, and had filed a suit (CS(COMM) 253/2019) against the Respondent on May 10, 2019, without challenging the validity of the Respondent's trademark registration.

**Arguments:**

* The Respondent argued that the Petitioner's rectification petition is not maintainable, relying on the judgment of the Supreme Court in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors. (2018) 2 SCC 112, and a Coordinate Bench of the Delhi High Court in Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr. (2021) 88 PTC 610. The Respondent claimed that the Petitioner should have framed a preliminary issue on the alleged invalidity of the Respondent's trademark in the earlier suit.
* The Petitioner argued that the impugned trademark registration is not in issue in the earlier suit (CS(COMM) 253/2019), where the Petitioner claimed proprietary rights over the trademark "NOW" and "NOW" formative marks, including "ENOW". The Petitioner sought an injunction against the Respondent's use of the trademarks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW", which are different from the trademark registration No. 1252812.

**Court Findings:**
The Court heard the arguments of both parties and considered the relevant provisions of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, specifically Section 30(2)(e) and Section 124(1). The Court noted that the Petitioner was aware of the Respondent's trademark registration since June 6, 2018, and had filed a suit against the Respondent without challenging the validity of the Respondent's trademark registration.

**Decision:**
The Court decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text. However, based on the arguments and the legal issues presented, it appears that the Court may dismiss the Petitioner's rectification petition, holding that it is not maintainable due to the Petitioner's failure to challenge the validity of the Respondent's trademark registration in the earlier suit. The Court may rely on the judgments cited by the Respondent, which suggest that a preliminary issue on the alleged invalidity of the Respondent's trademark should have been framed in the earlier suit before filing a rectification petition.

(i) if any proceedings for rectification of the register in relation to the 
plaintiff‘s or defendant‘s trade mark are pending before the Registrar 
or the Appellate Board, stay the suit pending the final disposal of such 
proceedings; 
(ii) if no such proceedings are pending and the court is satisfied that 
the plea regarding the invalidity of the registration of the plaintiff’s 
or defendant’s trade mark is prima facie tenable, raise an issue 
regarding the same and adjourn the case for a period of three 
months from the date of the framing of the issue in order to enable

of the register.‖

of Section 124 (1) (a) is attracted in the present case. 
13. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 has relied upon paragraphs 31 and 32 
of the judgment in Patel Field Marshal Agencies (supra). The same are set 
out below: 
―31.  Rather, from the résumé of the provisions of the 1958 Act made 
above, it becomes clear that all questions with regard to the validity 
of a trade mark is required to be decided by the Registrar or the High 
Court under the 1958 Act or by the Registrar or the IPAB under the 
1999 Act and not by the civil court. The civil court, in fact, is not 
empowered by the Act to decide the said question. Furthermore, the 
Act mandates that the decisions rendered by the prescribed statutory

authority [Registrar/High Court (now IPAB)] will bind the civil court. 
At the same time, the Act (both old and new) goes on to provide a 
different procedure to govern the exercise of the same jurisdiction in 
two different situations. In a case where the issue of invalidity is 
raised or arises independent of a suit, the prescribed statutory 
authority will be the sole authority to deal with the matter. However, 
in a situation where a suit is pending (whether instituted before or 
after the filing of a rectification application) the exercise of 
jurisdiction by the prescribed statutory authority is contingent on a 
finding of the civil court as regards the prima facie tenability of the 
plea of invalidity. 
32.  
Conversely, in a situation where the civil court does not find a 
triable issue on the plea of invalidity the remedy of an aggrieved party 
would not be to move under Sections 46/56 of the 1958 Act but to 
challenge the order of the civil court in appeal. This would be 
necessary to avoid multiple proceedings on the same issue and 
resultant conflict of decisions.‖ 
 
14. 
In the aforesaid judgment, relied upon by the respondent no.1, the 
defendants had contested the validity of the plaintiffs’ trade mark “Field 
Marshal” in their written statement and claimed that the same was liable to 
be rectified by the Trademark Registry. Similarly, in Resilient Innovations 
Pvt. Ltd. (supra), in the written statement filed on behalf of the petitioner 
therein (the defendant in the suit between the parties), it was pleaded that the 
registration in favour of the plaintiff therein was invalid. Therefore, the 
aforesaid cases were covered under Section 124 (1) (a) of the Trade Marks 
Act, 1999, which is not the case of the respondent no.1 here. Hence, the 
aforesaid judgments would not come to the aid of the respondent no.1.  
15. 
In my considered view, the mark “

According to the PDF document "Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf", a legal proceeding (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022) was held at the High Court of Delhi on November 28, 2022. The petitioner, Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, was represented by advocates Mr. Hemant Singh, Mrs. Mamta Rani Jha, and Mr. Amitesh Mishra. The respondent, E1, was accused of using the trademarks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW", which the petitioner claimed were similar to their mark "NOW".

The court considered sections 30(2)(e) and 124(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, which pertain to the limits on the effect of a registered trademark and the stay of proceedings where the validity of registration is questioned. The respondent argued that the judgments relied upon by the petitioner were not applicable in this case.

The court reviewed the plaint in CS(COMM) 253/2019 and noted that the cause of action was the respondent's claim of rights over the marks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW". The petitioner sought a decree of permanent injunction against the respondent's use of these marks, which were deemed deceptively similar to the petitioner's mark "E NOW". The mark "/E!" was not the subject matter of the suit, but was mentioned in the respondent's written statement as a registered mark. (Source: Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf, pages 1-4)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf", a legal case was heard in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (Case No. 2022/DHC/005230, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022). The petitioner, Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, was represented by advocates Mr. Hemant Singh, Mrs. Mamta Rani Jha, and Mr. Amitesh Mishra.

The respondent No.1 had filed a written statement pleading that the mark "/E!" was registered in their favor, but did not file a suit to restrain the petitioner from using the mark. The petitioner argued that the respondent No.1 had not raised a defense under Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and that Section 124(1)(b) was not applicable in this case.

The respondent No.1 relied on the judgment in Patel Field Marshal Agencies, which stated that the civil court is not empowered to decide on the validity of a trade mark. However, the court noted that the respondent No.1 had not pleaded that the registered marks of the plaintiff were identical or nearly resembled each other, and therefore Section 124(1)(a) was not attracted in this case.

The court decision was made on November 28, 2022. The document is digitally signed by Amit Bansal on December 1, 2022. The case highlights the importance of proper pleading and the application of relevant sections of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, in intellectual property disputes. (Source: Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf)

nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf", the court discusses the jurisdiction of statutory authorities and civil courts in matters of trademark invalidity. The court notes that in situations where a suit is pending, the exercise of jurisdiction by the prescribed statutory authority is contingent on a finding of the civil court regarding the prima facie tenability of the plea of invalidity. The court also references a previous judgment, stating that it does not apply to the current case as it falls under a different section of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The case, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022, was decided on November 28, 2022. The petitioners, Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, were represented by advocates Mr. Hemant Singh, Mrs. Mamta Rani Jha, and Mr. Amitesh Mishra. (Source: 9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf, page 6)

authority [Registrar/High Court (now IPAB)] will bind the civil court. 
At the same time, the Act (both old and new) goes on to provide a 
different procedure to govern the exercise of the same jurisdiction in 
two different situations. In a case where the issue of invalidity is 
raised or arises independent of a suit, the prescribed statutory 
authority will be the sole authority to deal with the matter. However, 
in a situation where a suit is pending (whether instituted before or 
after the filing of a rectification application) the exercise of 
jurisdiction by the prescribed statutory authority is contingent on a 
finding of the civil court as regards the prima facie tenability of the 
plea of invalidity. 
32.  
Conversely, in a situation where the civil court does not find a 
triable issue on the plea of invalidity the remedy of an aggrieved party 
would not be to move under Sections 46/56 of the 1958 Act but to 
challenge the order of the civil court in appeal. This would be 
necessary to avoid multiple proceedings on the same issue and 
resultant conflict of decisions.‖ 
 
14. 
In the aforesaid judgment, relied upon by the respondent no.1, the 
defendants had contested the validity of the plaintiffs’ trade mark “Field 
Marshal” in their written statement and claimed that the same was liable to 
be rectified by the Trademark Registry. Similarly, in Resilient Innovations 
Pvt. Ltd. (supra), in the written statement filed on behalf of the petitioner 
therein (the defendant in the suit between the parties), it was pleaded that the 
registration in favour of the plaintiff therein was invalid. Therefore, the 
aforesaid cases were covered under Section 124 (1) (a) of the Trade Marks 
Act, 1999, which is not the case of the respondent no.1 here. Hence, the 
aforesaid judgments would not come to the aid of the respondent no.1.

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the provided PDF document, "Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf", the Delhi High Court made a decision on November 28, 2022, in the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022. The petitioner, Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, was represented by advocates Mr. Hemant Singh, Mrs. Mamta Rani Jha, and Mr. Amitesh Mishra. 

The court ruled that Section 124 of the Trademarks Act, 1999, would not apply in this case, and therefore, the present application was dismissed. The respondent no.1 had filed an application (I.A. 4832/2022) seeking permission to file a counter statement/reply, which was granted. The respondent no.1 was allowed to file its counter statement/reply within four weeks, subject to payment of costs of Rs.50,000/- to the petitioner.

The court directed the respondent no.1 to file its counter statement/reply within four weeks and the petitioner to file a rejoinder, if any, within four weeks thereafter. The case was listed before the Joint Registrar for completion of pleadings on February 2, 2023, and before the Court on March 15, 2023. The decision was made by Judge Amit Bansal, who digitally signed the document on December 1, 2022. The PDF document (2022/DHC/005230) provides detailed information about the court proceedings, including the facts, arguments, and decisions made in the case.
